name: Inventory & Audit
step: Learn about the brand, the product and the stakeholders

content.title: Goal
content.text: A content inventory is a list of all the content attached to the project, including the application, documentation, images and any other assets. A content audit is an evaluation of that inventory to determine what needs improving, removing or left as is. Once both steps are complete you should have a good understanding of the current state of the project and potential ways to move forward.

content.title: Benefits
list: Understand existing content better, improving future maintenance
Helps to understand the scope of the project and find assets you didn't know existed
Useful for creating a strategy going forwards
Web analytics give a better idea of content effectiveness
Helps with ensure content aligns with both business goals and user needs

content.title: Prerequisites
list: None!

content.title: The Process
ordered: List all project assets, including files, pages, images
Document data associated with those files, including content type, goal, metadata, analytics
Document who owns the content if content is shared
Document page links when looking to improve navigation
Review each asset against for quality, consistency, performance, if it meets its goal, duplication etc
Review the status of each asset, does it need updating, deleting or is it ok as it is?
Prioritise actions based on user wants and client requests

content.title: Deliverables
list: A full project inventory
A project inventory audit evaluating what needs improving or removing
A report

content.title: Content Audit
content.caption: An example audit list

content.title: Priority Order
content.caption: With a content inventory and user/stakeholder requirements defined, work can be prioritised

name: Stakeholder Interviews
step: Learn about the brand, the product and the stakeholders

content.title: Goal
content.text: Interviews with project stakeholders offer useful insights into the collective mind of an organization. They can help you uncover areas of misalignment between a company’s documented strategy and the attitudes and day-to-day decision-making of stakeholders. They can also highlight issues that deserve special consideration due to their strategic importance to a business.

content.title: Benefits
list: Determine the business goals
Find out what is already known about the users
Learn the stakeholder’s background and story
Discover the currently known competitors
Find out about an technological or any other limitations

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Content Inventory & Audit - gives insight into existing product

content.title: The Process
ordered: Determine a list of stakeholders to interview, including senior, SMEs, marketing, sales and engineering
Create a list of questions for each stakeholder, limited to four major topics
Let interviewees know in advance what you’ll ask them, or at least the topics you plan to discuss
Prepare any useful documents found in the content inventory, including annual reports, strategy document, advertisements etc
Set aside at least 45 minutes for each interview
Discuss the culture, challenges and goals, not the features
Document the outcomes of each interview

content.title: Deliverables
list: Individual stakeholder interview notes
Summary document providing overview of picture built from all interviews

content.title: Stakeholder Interview Questions
content.caption: Create a questions library to produce personalised interviews from

name: User Interviews
step: Identify users thoughts, feelings and actions

content.title: Goal
content.text: User interviews allow you to speak directly to users and get responses to specific questions that you have. If done well, it could also uncover nuances or directions that were previously unknown or unthought of. Very often it is the most powerful way to find a truth about their behaviour (backed up with stories) that you otherwise may not consider.

content.title: Benefits
list: Get answers to outstanding questions
Discover directions not previously considered
Get a perspective outside the companies internal views
Gather knowledge required to generate user stories, personas and use cases

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Stakeholder Interviews - to determine how user needs align with stakeholder goals

content.title: The Process
ordered: Know what you want answered
Reframe the problem statements
Build a list of non-leading, open-ended questions
Give the list of questions a structure (intro, warm-up, main-body and wrap-up)
Document the outcomes of each interview

content.title: Deliverables
list: Individual user interview notes
A list of user scenarios

content.title: User Interview Summary
content.caption: Summary of a user interview

name: Competitive Analysis
step: Learn about the brand, the product and the stakeholders

content.title: Goal
content.text: To identify your competitors and evaluate their strategies to determine their strengths and weaknesses relative to those of your own product or service. This will help to identify compelling competitive advantages that could be introduced as well as a good market fit. Remember this solution needs to feel organic to your users’ needs, while being clear to all involved how the competitor research has informed it.

content.title: Benefits
list: Learn what solutions others offer
Learn what others do well and not so well
Learn what mistakes others have previously made
Helps determine where your current solution fits
Helps to identify what your solution needs to offer

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Content Inventory & Audit - gives insight into existing product
Stakeholder Interviews – gives insight to unique business goals
User Interviews – gives insight to user needs

content.title: The Process
ordered: Define the competition including direct and indirect competitors
Define the assessment criteria
Conduct the research by filling out a spreadsheet containing the competitors against the the assessment criteria
Summarise your findings
Present your findings

content.title: Deliverables
list: An in-depth analysis of each of the identified competitors’ products
Screenshots along with annotations explaining the specifics of each feature/UX flow
Feature list and/or approximate sitemap of each competitor’s platform/product
Strengths and areas of improvement for each of the analyzed products
Competitor analysis matrix — A table that contains a column for features and separate columns for if each competitor has that feature

content.title: Competitor Analysis Matrix
content.caption: Competitor Analysis Matrix

name: Persona Workshop
step: Model experiences, tasks and mindsets for goals, and define and frame the problem

content.title: Goal
content.text: A persona is a way to model, summarise and communicate research about people in a condensed way. Each persona represents a significant number of people in the real world but is depicted as a specific person. This enables designers to focus on a manageable and memorable cast of characters, instead of focusing on thousands of individuals and helps with creating different designs for different people.

content.title: Benefits
list: Builds empathy with users
Develops focus by having clear user types to develop for
Helps communicate interview findings with others in a concise way
Helps to defend decisions made based on real data

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Interviews

content.title: The Process
ordered: Ensure enough users have been interviewed
Find patterns in responses and actions and use those to group similar people together
Create archetypical models of those groups based on the patterns found, including demographic info, backgrounds, goals, motivations and pain points
Share those models with other team members and stakeholders

content.title: Deliverables
list: A handful of personas summarising the user base

content.title: Persona Demographic
content.caption: Persona Demographic

content.title: Persona Background
content.caption: Persona Background

content.title: Persona Goals
content.caption: Persona Goals

content.title: Persona Motivations
content.caption: Persona Motivations

content.title: Persona Further Info
content.caption: Persona Further Info

name: Journey Mapping
step: Model experiences, tasks and mindsets for goals, and define and frame the problem

content.title: Goal
content.text: A User Journey is used to visualise a structured narrative of what a user does, thinks and feels. This can be used to review the current user experience, identify gaps, pain points and opportunities to improve things where possible.

content.title: Benefits
list: Builds empathy with users
Helps to document full user flows for each of their goals
Identify potential points of improvement in the user experience

content.title: Prerequisites
list: User Interviews
Personas

content.title: The Process
ordered: Gather previously defined user scenarios and personas into one place
For each persona draw out the each scenario/task the user completes to achieve their goal
Analyse interview notes and personas for each task and write out what the user is thinking and how they are feeling
Identify pain points in the flow
Brainstorm potential solutions to these pain points

content.title: Deliverables
list: A journey map for each personas summarising their workflow
A list of potential opportunities to improve different user experiences

content.title: Journey Mapping Template
content.caption: A template for creating a User Journey Map

content.title: Journey Mapping Example
content.caption: An example of how a User Journey looks once complete

name: Event Storming
step: Identify users thoughts, feelings and actions

content.title: Goal
content.text: Event storming is a rapid design technique that establishes a common and shared language between Business & IT. It sets focus in terms of scope and boundaries and gives you the big picture of the solution by placing technical implementation details in context of the business process. It will also help identify key views for your user interface, which can jump start Site Mapping and Wireframing.

content.title: Benefits
list: Share understanding about business objectives and project/product goals
Supports group learning and is a fun way to integrate development and product teams
Help the development team get to know the client’s business better
Can help to identify bottlenecks and areas of conflict

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Persona Workshop
Journey Mapping

content.title: The Process
ordered: Invite a mixture of stakeholders representing user experience, business, architecture, development, and IT
Provide unlimited modeling space
Using previously gathered personas and journeys, explore the business domain by identifying domain events
Evaluate each event for its causes and consequences (commands)
Connect events to reactions, what happens as a result of the event
Use domain-driven design to define the structure of your system
This process can be repeated working on what had been completed in the previous session with different stakeholders

content.title: Deliverables
list: An event-driven system model containing UI requirements and data models
A unified view and language between all parts of the organisation

content.title: Event Storming Domain Events
content.caption: Start of be listing out domain events

content.title: Event Storming Commands
content.caption: Add commands to events to list causes and consequences

content.title: Event Storming Reactions
content.caption: Add reactions to events to list what happens as a result of the event

content.title: Event Storming Business Process
content.caption: Define the business process by structuring the result of the previous steps

content.title: Event Storming Example
content.caption: An example of what Event Storming can look like

name: Story Mapping
step: Identify users thoughts, feelings and actions

content.title: Goal
content.text: A technique completed collaboratively to help visualise the project scope and create a backlog by mapping out the user stories with regards to complete user journeys. The activity should involve the designers, developers, product owner and ideally any stakeholders and SMEs in order to bridge the gap between design and development. Seeing the bigger picture helps to determine priorities and prevent focusing too much on individual stories.

content.title: Benefits
list: Visualise how all user stories link together
Gain a unified agreement of the project scope and priority
Designers understand risks and feasibility and developers understand user goals
Focuses on helping users achieve their goals rather than on adding features

content.title: Prerequisites
list: Persona Workshop
Journey Mapping
Event Storming

content.title: The Process
ordered: Set up a list of participants
Identify and discuss user and business goals
Discuss User Personas and how the new product will be beneficial over existing solutions
Create narrative flows, breaking down goals into features, features into epics (user tasks) and epics into user stories
Break down user stories into tasks and sub-tasks where necessary
Consider additional paths and variations, including errors and edge cases
Slice user stories and tasks into releases using Red Route Analysis

content.title: Deliverables
list: A user story map containing stories and tasks grouped and prioritised into releases

content.title: Story Mapping layout
content.caption: Example layout

content.title: Story Mapping alternative layout
content.caption: An alternative layout

content.title: Story Map Slicing
content.caption: Breaking down user stories into releases

content.title: Red Route Analysis
content.caption: Use Red Route Analysis to help slice up user stories into releases
